intro: Zosterophyllanthos sarcochilus, commonly known as the ghost orchid, is a rare and enigmatic flowering plant native to the tropical regions of Southeast Asia. It is characterized by its unique, elongated leaves that resemble tendrils and its striking, showy flowers that often display a mix of white, purple, and green hues. The plant is epiphytic, meaning it grows on the surfaces of trees without deriving nutrients from them, relying instead on air and rain for sustenance. Its botanical features make it highly sought after by botanists and conservationists due to its ecological significance and declining population. Due to habitat loss and over-collection, it is considered vulnerable, highlighting the need for conservation efforts to protect this rare species.
